conversation:
Persuader: Hey, how are you doing, have you ever heard of a charity called Save the Children? [Initiate conversation and introduce the topic of a charity]
Persuadee: No I havent. [Respond to the question and indicate lack of knowledge about the charity]
Persuadee: What is it about? [Request more information about the charity]
Persuader: It's an international organization that promotes children's rights, provides relief and helps support children in developing countries, does that sound like something you'd get behind? [Provide information about the charity and gauge interest]
Persuadee: No thank you. [Decline interest in the charity]
Persuader: May I ask why? [Seek reasons for the lack of interest]
Persuader: Your help could really make a difference in a child's life, think of a child who didn't have enough to eat, just a small bit of help may have saved them, are you sure you're not interested? [Attempt to persuade by emphasizing the impact of the help]
Persuadee: I am already making a difference in many children lives. [State current involvement in helping children]
Persuader: That's great, it sounds like it's an issue you really care about then, why not put some of that effort into a charity that's doing really great work like Save the Children? [Acknowledge the effort and suggest contributing to the specific charity]
Persuadee: I have donated 15 years of my life to charity [Highlight past significant contributions to charity]
Persuader: I'm not asking you to donate years of your life, just a couple of cents if possible, is that something you could possibly do tonight? [Clarify the request for a small monetary donation]
Persuadee: No thank you [Decline the request again]
Persuader: You're probably on a computer right now, so you probably have quite a bit of money yourself, don't you think you could spare maybe 25 cents for some needy children around the world? [Attempt to persuade by suggesting the affordability of a small donation]

Persuader: Absolutely. [Agreeing with the previous statement]

Persuader: Exactly. [Agreeing with the sentiment expressed]

conversation:
Persuader: Hello. [Greeting the other person.]
Persuader: I have a story to share with you. [Introducing the purpose of the conversation.]
Persuadee: Of course im hear to listen . [Expressing willingness to listen.]
Persuader: I just donated to Save the Children and feel like it will be super helpful. [Sharing a recent charitable action.]
Persuader: There was a child who died of hunger and I think my donation will help other children. [Providing context and reasoning for the donation.]
Persuadee: Yes i believe it most DEFINETLY will make a big impact on others lives and its amazing to see such kind hearted people like yourself do so. [Affirming the positive impact of the donation and complimenting the speaker.]
Persuader: Thanks! [Expressing gratitude.]
Persuader: I just read that The United Nations estimated last year 25,000 people still die of hunger daily. [Sharing a fact to emphasize the severity of the issue.]
Persuader: That means more than 9.1 million people die of hunger every year. [Providing additional context to highlight the problem.]
Persuadee: Yes its such a sad thing to see happen myself and family are very kind hearted and feel for all the people around the world who are suffering from this , And would love to make a change and to help . [Expressing empathy and a desire to help.]
Persuader: Great to hear there are still kind hearted people to help people suffering! [Expressing appreciation for others' kindness.]
Persuader: It makes me angry to know of so many children in danger in the world. [Expressing frustration about the issue.]
Persuadee: Yes its so sad how people can go about their day and not think of those who are in great need ! [Agreeing and expressing sadness about the situation.]
Persuadee: Especially those who are very wealthy themselves and don't care to make a difference [Criticizing wealthy individuals who do not help.]
Persuader: I agree! [Agreeing with the previous statement.]
Persuader: I certainly am not wealthy but still try to make donation as often as I can. [Sharing personal financial status and commitment to donating.]
Persuader: There are some wealthy people that are great philanthropists, but I think more people like you and I are needed to make even small donations. [Emphasizing the importance of small donations from many people.]
Persuader: Have you ever been to the Save the Children website?  URL [Inquiring if the other person is familiar with the charity.]
Persuadee: Yes most definitely i totally agree with you! [Agreeing with the previous statement.]
Persuadee: Yes i do i actually watch a family on youtube that raises money every year live streaming for save the children and all the money they receive goes to save the children [Sharing personal experience related to the charity.]
Persuader: You can make a donation from your incoming earning from this task to Save the Children. [Suggesting a way to donate.]
Persuader: Even just a small amount makes a difference? [Encouraging even small donations.]
Persuader: I just realized I sound like a telemarketer! [Self-reflecting on the tone of the conversation.]
Persuader: Can you donate part of your payment? [Directly asking for a donation.]
Persuader: I think we should. [Expressing a collective responsibility to donate.]
Persuadee: As of right now i honestly would but i dont have the funds for it if their are other ways im albe to get others to donate as well and help out in any way possible i will be more then willing to do so.. [Explaining current financial constraints and willingness to help in other ways.]
Persuader: Even just a small donation helps. [Reiterating the value of small donations.]

conversation:
Persuader: Hi there. [Greeting the other person.]
Persuader: Have you ever thought about who the most vulnerable people are when a natural disaster strikes? [Introducing a thought-provoking question about vulnerable people during natural disasters.]
Persuader: Or when there's political unrest? [Expanding the context to include political unrest.]
Persuadee: That is something I do not think about. [Expressing a lack of prior consideration on the topic.]
Persuader: Actually, I'm really troubled by the answer. [Expressing personal concern about the issue.]
Persuader: In countries like Syria, 1000 children have been killed during the civil war. [Providing a specific example to illustrate the concern.]
Persuader: Isn't that insane? [Seeking agreement or reaction to the provided example.]
Persuadee: That is terrible. [Expressing sympathy and agreement with the concern.]
Persuadee: I wish this wasn't true. [Expressing a wish that the situation were different.]
Persuader: Seriously. [Affirming the previous statement.]
Persuader: Adults often can't fend for themselves when there's a crisis, but children are especially vulnerable. [Highlighting the particular vulnerability of children in crises.]
Persuader: Do you think that if you could do something to help Syrian children or children in Indonesia, which just experienced an earthquake, you would?. [Asking if the other person would be willing to help children in crisis situations.]
Persuadee: That would be something I would do, yes. [Expressing willingness to help.]
Persuader: Yeah, me too. [Expressing agreement and shared sentiment.]
Persuader: Every day I watch the news and hear about victims all over the world and feel kind of powerless. [Sharing personal feelings of powerlessness in the face of global issues.]
Persuadee: You have more power than you realize. [Encouraging the other person by suggesting they have more power than they realize.]
Persuader: Can you elaborate. [Requesting further explanation.]
Persuader: How do you think people like us could help? [Asking for specific ideas on how people can help.]
Persuadee: We could either donate money or our time. [Suggesting ways to help  such as donating money or time.]

Persuader: It just sucks that millions of Syrian children have grown up facing the daily threat of violence. [To highlight the plight of Syrian children to evoke empathy]

Persuader: To talk about suffering people and children for a minute? [Clarifying the request to discuss suffering people and children]
Persuadee: I will have no discomfort discussing suffering people. [Reassuring that discussing suffering people is acceptable]
Persuader: I think the refugee crisis is crazy, I am not sure what I would do if I was raising my kids in Syria. [Expressing personal opinion on the refugee crisis]
Persuader: If anyone could have fun in those spots it's kids though. [Attempting to find a positive aspect in a dire situation]
Persuadee: I feel really torn about the crisis. [Expressing conflicted feelings about the crisis]
Persuadee: I don't think the weight of that burden should fall on the rest of the worlds shoulders. [Stating a belief about the responsibility of the global community]
Persuadee: At the same time as a parent I would want the best possible future for my children and I know fiercly that I would do everything in my power to make sure they were in a safe place. [Relating personal parental instincts to the situation]
Persuader: I actually didn't think of it like that. [Expressing a new perspective gained from the conversation]
Persuader: I am a parent too, it feels so foreign what they are going through. [Relating personal experience as a parent to the situation]
Persuader: This whole chat thing is supposed to get me to get you to donate to Save the Children, but now I think they got me to do it instead! [Revealing the purpose of the conversation (to solicit donations)]

Persuadee: With that all said I do feel like any orginazation that aims to help the children I am more inclined to donate to them than most. [Expressing a preference for donating to organizations that help children]

conversation:
Persuader: I am so livid I just can't stand it right now. [Expressing strong emotion and frustration]
Persuader: Parts of this world are so dark... [Commenting on the negative aspects of the world]
Persuader: how can we sit here and do nothing? [Questioning inaction in the face of suffering]
Persuadee: Do nothing about what? [Seeking clarification]
Persuader: These poor suffering children! [Highlighting the issue of suffering children]
Persuader: Did you know that 5.6 million children die each year due to treatable AND preventable diseases? [Providing a shocking statistic to emphasize the issue]
Persuadee: That's awful. [Expressing sympathy]
Persuadee: Are you talking about around the world or in the states? [Seeking clarification on the scope of the issue]
Persuader: Around the world! [Clarifying the scope as global]
Persuader: There is so much that could be done.. [Expressing the potential for positive action]
Persuader: between preventing the spread of aids, reducing the infant mortality rate with proper education and vaccinations, and ensuring access and aid to proper nutrition so many children could be saved. [Listing specific actions that could help]
Persuadee: I totally agree. [Agreeing with the points made]
Persuadee: There are people helping but its a drop in the bucket. [Acknowledging efforts but noting their insufficiency]
Persuadee: The kids dying is really disturbing. [Expressing disturbance at the situation]
Persuadee: They didn't choose that life. [Empathizing with the children]
Persuader: You are absolutely right. [Agreeing with EE's point]
Persuader: It is disturbing! [Reiterating the disturbing nature of the issue]
Persuader: And yes, it could seem like the aid is a drop in a bucket. [Acknowledging the perception of aid as minimal]
Persuader: However, if we can move the scale one iota and can consider that what that represents is one child having a week of meals or a healthy 3 months than wouldn't you agree that that would be worth any aid that we could provide? [Arguing that even small contributions are valuable]
Persuadee: Absolutely! [Agreeing strongly]
Persuadee: I think every little bit helps but as a whole it's not enough. [Reiterating that small efforts help but are not enough]
Persuadee: Have you ever donated? [Inquiring about ER's personal involvement]
Persuader: I have! [Confirming personal involvement]
Persuader: And it feels incredible knowing that I have been a part of something greater than myself. [Describing the positive feelings from contributing]
Persuader: It really helps you shift your perspective about your own personal significance on this planet. [Discussing the shift in perspective from helping]
Persuader: You realize how infinitely important you are and yet at the same time how infinitely important another person is. [Reflecting on the importance of individuals]
Persuader: When you have the ability to literally change another person's life with something so small... [Emphasizing the impact of small actions]
Persuader: wow, it's life changing. [Expressing awe at the impact]
Persuadee: That is great! [Complimenting ER's passion]
Persuadee: you sound very passionate about this subject. [Noting ER's passion for the subject]
Persuadee: I should do more to help. [Expressing a desire to help more]
Persuader: You should! [Encouraging EE to take action]

conversation:
Persuader: Hello, have you heard of Save The Children? [Initiate conversation and introduce the topic of Save The Children]
Persuadee: I think so, it sounds familiar. [Express familiarity with the topic]
Persuadee: it is a nonprofit charity if i recall. [Confirm understanding of the organization as a nonprofit charity]
Persuadee: What exactly do they do? [Seek more detailed information about the organization's activities]
Persuader: Save The Children helps kids from around the world by taking contributions from generous patrons. Kids from countries that have been stricken by poverty, violence, and other blights. [Provide detailed information about the organization's mission and activities]
Persuadee: What countries has the charity worked in recently? [Inquire about specific countries where the charity has recently worked]
Persuader: Well, we have programs set up in 120 countries in total right now. [Provide information about the scope of the organization's programs]
Persuader: Some of our most recent campaigns involve Myanmar - in Rohingya where parents and their children have been forced to flee because of violence to surrounding countries. In the largest refugee camp stationed in Bangladesh, there are an estimated 915,000 children and adults taking shelter. [Give specific examples of recent campaigns and their impact]
Persuadee: Wow that sounds like a really robust program. [Express admiration for the organization's efforts]
Persuadee: How long has Save the Children been around? [Inquire about the history of the organization]
Persuader: It was founded in 1919, on April 15th in London - UK. [Provide historical information about the organization's founding]
Persuadee: Do you work for Save the Children or do you just volunteer for the charity? [Inquire about the speaker's relationship with the organization]
Persuader: I do not work for them, I work on behalf of them. [Clarify the nature of their involvement with the organization]
Persuader: That is why I'm talking to you today. [Explain the purpose of the current conversation]
Persuader: These children need help, and could use it from generous people like you. [Emphasize the need for help and appeal for support]
Persuader: A meal, an education, an opportunity like everyone else, that is all these kids want. [Highlight the basic needs of the children the organization helps]
Persuader: Even one cent will add up to help a child in need, but if you wish you may donate up to 2 dollars. [Explain the donation process and suggest donation amounts]
Persuader: For every cent you donate it will come directly from your task payment. [Clarify how donations will be deducted]
Persuadee: I love to help charities that serve a good cause and I would love to donate but I do have one question. [Express willingness to donate but indicate a need for more information]
Persuadee: What is the portion of donations that goes to children versus the portion that goes to administration or other expenses [Inquire about the allocation of donations between direct aid and administrative costs]
Persuader: Sure, absolutely. In 2017, 86% went to Program services - or services that directly help aid these children. 9% went towards fundraising efforts, and 5% went towards our Management & other general costs. In 2018 we anticipate similar numbers. [Provide detailed information about the allocation of donations]

conversation:
Persuader: Donate to Save the Children, please. [Requesting donation]
Persuader: Think about those poor kids. [Appealing to empathy]
Persuadee: Well tell me a little bit more about the charity. [Requesting more information]
Persuader: It's really all in the name. [Deflecting request for information]
Persuader: You have a moral responsibility. [Appealing to moral responsibility]
Persuadee: A lot of charities are just a name and they don't do what they promise. [Expressing skepticism]
Persuadee: How do I know my money will go where it supposed to? [Seeking assurance about fund allocation]
Persuader: They're a world-famous trustworthy charity. [Providing assurance about trustworthiness]
Persuader: If they were fraudulent or misallocating funds, surely there'd have been a scandal. [Providing rationale for trustworthiness]
Persuadee: Ok. [Indicating tentative agreement]
Persuadee: So why do they deserve my money as opposed to other charities like St Judes or the Red Cross> [Questioning the uniqueness of the charity]
Persuader: Of course you can donate to other charities. [Conceding the possibility of donating to other charities]
Persuader: It's not necessarily a zero-sum game. [Clarifying that donations are not mutually exclusive]
Persuader: I can tell you, however, that Save the Children is, in a way, more immediate in helping people (as opposed to fighting disease like St Jude's) and delivers services similar to the Red Cross, but directed toward children. [Explaining the unique impact of the charity]
Persuader: So, please: think of the children! [Reiterating appeal to empathy]
Persuadee: Do they help kids in the US? [Inquiring about the charity's scope]
Persuadee: I like to help people that are close to home. [Expressing preference for local impact]
Persuader: Their assistance is directed toward children in developing countries, where, unlike most of the US, children are totally deprived of opportunity and basic services. [Clarifying the charity's focus on developing countries]
